Shane_McAnally:
{{short description|American musician and songwriter (born 1974)}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Shane McAnally | image = Shane.Headshot.2019.jpg | image_size = | background = solo_singer | caption = McAnally in 2019 | alt = A headshot of Shane McAnally | birth_name = Shane Lamar McAnally | alias = Shane Mack | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1974|10|12}} | origin = [[Mineral Wells, Texas]], United States | genre = [[Country music|Country]] | label = [[Curb Records|Curb]] | spouse = {{marriage|Michael Baum|2017}} | occupation = {{hlist|Singer|songwriter|record producer}} | years_active = {{hlist|1999–2000|2005–present}} }} '''Shane Lamar McAnally''' (born October 12, 1974) is an American [[country music]] singer, songwriter, and record producer. He debuted as a singer in 1999 with his [[Shane McAnally (album)|self-titled album]] on [[Curb Records]]. This project produced three singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts, including "[[Are Your Eyes Still Blue]]". After a hiatus from music, McAnally returned to songwriting, having his first major success with "[[Last Call (Lee Ann Womack song)|Last Call]]" by [[Lee Ann Womack]] in 2008. From the early 2010s onward, McAnally has worked almost exclusively as a songwriter and producer. Artists with whom he has worked include [[Old Dominion (band)|Old Dominion]], [[Midland (band)|Midland]], and [[Kacey Musgraves]]. He has won three Grammy Awards and multiple awards from the [[Country Music Association]] (CMA). In 2023, he collaborated with [[Brandy Clark]] in writing the musical ''[[Shucked]]''. ==Musical career== [[File:FOCO ShaneMcAnally.jpg|200px|thumb|McAnally in 2017.]] Shane Lamar McAnally was born October 12, 1974, in [[Mineral Wells, Texas]]. He began performing at local clubs at the age of 12 and appeared on ''[[Star Search]]'' when he was 14, singing [[Dan Hill]]'s "[[Sometimes When We Touch]]." He moved to [[Branson, Missouri]] at 15, then to Nashville at 19.{{cite news|last1=Rodman|first1=Sarah|title=Songwriter Spotlight: Shane McAnally Tells Stories Behind the Hits|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/features/songwriter-spotlight-shane-mcanally-tells-stories-behind-the-hits-20150219|access-date=26 April 2015|publisher=Rolling Stone|date=19 February 2015}} McAnally and [[music producer]] Rich Herring recorded a demo of a song that McAnally had written. The song, "Just One Touch", earned McAnally a publishing deal as well as a recording contract with [[Curb Records]].{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/shane-mcanally-p373945/biography|title=Shane McAnally : Allmusic : Biography|publisher=[[Allmusic]]|access-date=June 2, 2011}} In 1999, McAnally signed with Curb and began recording his first album for the label as well as his first single. "Say Anything" was released in 1999 as his debut single. The song peaked at No. 41 on the US ''Billboard'' [[Hot Country Songs]] chart. The follow-up single, "[[Are Your Eyes Still Blue]]", became his only top 40 single as a singer, peaking at No. 31. McAnally charted a third and final time with "Run Away", which reached No. 50. All three tracks appeared on a [[Shane McAnally (album)|self-titled debut album]] released on Curb in 2000 before he left the label.{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Hot Country Songs 1944 to 2008|publisher=Record Research, Inc|date=2008|page=261|isbn=978-0-89820-177-2}} ===Songwriting=== {{Main|List of songs written by Shane McAnally}} In 2001, McAnally moved to [[Los Angeles]]. He composed six songs for the soundtrack of 2007 independent film ''[[Shelter (2007 film)|Shelter]]'', credited as Shane Mack.{{cite news|last1=Rosen|first1=Jody|title=Shane McAnally, Out and Riding High in Nashville|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/26/arts/music/out-and-riding-high-in-nashville.html|access-date=28 September 2016|work=The New York Times|date=May 24, 2013}} Returning to Nashville in late 2007, McAnally began writing songs for other artists, starting with "[[Last Call (Lee Ann Womack song)|Last Call]]", released by [[Lee Ann Womack]] in 2008. From this point onward, McAnally has been primarily known for his songwriting work. He has also worked as a [[record producer]], for artists such as [[Kacey Musgraves]], [[Old Dominion (band)|Old Dominion]], and [[Midland (band)|Midland]]. He has written and produced songs for [[Walker Hayes]], [[Kacey Musgraves]], [[Kelly Clarkson]], [[Sam Hunt]], [[Kenny Chesney]], [[Reba McEntire]], [[Jake Owen]], [[Luke Bryan]], [[The Band Perry]], [[Lady A]], [[Keith Urban]], [[Thomas Rhett]], [[Brothers Osborne]], [[Old Dominion (band)|Old Dominion]], [[Dierks Bentley]], [[Miranda Lambert]], [[Kelsea Ballerini]], [[Midland (band)|Midland]], and more. The [[Academy of Country Music]] named him Songwriter of the Year in 2014. He also won "Best Country Album" and "Best Country Song" at the 2014 [[Grammy Award]]s for his work on [[Kacey Musgraves]]'s ''[[Same Trailer Different Park]]''. In 2015, ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' named him the Hot Country Songwriter of the Year as well as a ''Billboard'' Power Player. McAnally joined industry veteran [[Jason Owen (talent manager)|Jason Owen]] in early 2017 to relaunch [[Monument Records]] as co-presidents.{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/business/7669714/monument-records-sony-music-label|title=Sony Music's Monument Records Revived By Jason Owen, Shane McAnally Biography|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|access-date=September 17, 2019}} McAnally stars as one of the on-screen talent producers in the NBC television reality series ''[[Songland]]''.{{cite magazine|url=https://www.nbc.com/songland/credits/producer/shane-mcanally|title=Shane McAnally: Songland Producer|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|access-date=September 17, 2019}} In 2019, McAnally won the [[Academy of Country Music Awards|ACM]] Award for Songwriter of the Year and [[Grammy Award]] for Best Country Song for co-writing [[Kacey Musgraves]]'s "[[Space Cowboy (Kacey Musgraves song)|Space Cowboy]]."[http://www.grammy.com/grammys/news/2019-61st-annual-grammy-awards-nominations-complete-nominees-and-winners-list “61st GRAMMY Awards: Full Nominees & Winners List.”] GRAMMY.com, Recording Academy, 18 Feb. 2020. Most recently, he was named as one of Billboard's 2020 Country Power Players and chosen as the recipient of the 2020 Billboard Trailblazer Award, held only by previous winners [[Reba McEntire]] and [[Florida Georgia Line]]. McAnally received a nomination for the [[Grammy Award for Songwriter of the Year, Non-Classical]] at the [[66th Annual Grammy Awards]] for his work on songs by [[Brandy Clark]], [[Walker Hayes]], [[Lauren Daigle]], [[Old Dominion (band)|Old Dominion]], [[Alex Newell]], [[Niall Horan]], [[Sam Hunt]], [[Carly Pearce]], and [[Chris Stapleton]], as well as a nomination for [[Grammy Award for Best Musical Theater Album|Best Musical Theater Album]] for his work on ''[[Shucked]]''.{{Cite web |title=2024 GRAMMY Nominations: See The Full Nominees List {{!}} GRAMMY.com |url=https://www.grammy.com/news/2024-grammys-nominations-full-winners-nominees-list |access-date=2023-11-12 |website=www.grammy.com}} ==Personal life== McAnally told [[Yahoo! Entertainment]] in 2020 that he struggled with his sexuality for many years while working in Nashville, as he knew that no country music singers were openly gay at the time. At the time, he was dating a woman to whom he later [[coming out|came out]], although he kept his orientation hidden from others and later referred to his girlfriend as a [[Beard (companion)|beard]].{{cite web | url=https://www.yahoo.com/video/country-hitmaker-shane-mc-anally-on-coming-out-i-was-so-afraid-of-what-it-would-mean-to-my-career-225156865.html#:~:text=Last%20year%20on%20Songland%2C%20judge,and%20one%20of%20the%20most | title=Country hitmaker Shane McAnally on coming out: 'I was so afraid of what it would mean to my career' | publisher=Yahoo! Entertainment | date=June 9, 2020 | accessdate=August 24, 2022}} After exiting Curb in 2000, McAnally decided to come out while living in [[West Hollywood, California]], a city he knew was more accepting of the gay community. He worked songwriter shows there and chose to return to Nashville due to his enjoyment of music. McAnally received attention as a gay musician in 2013 when he co-wrote and co-produced "[[Follow Your Arrow]]" by Kacey Musgraves, a song which features a lyric in support of the gay community. McAnally married his partner of five years, Michael Baum, in September 2012. The couple have two children. In January 2017, the two were legally married by Nashville Mayor [[Megan Barry]].[https://musicrow.com/2017/01/musicrowlife-shane-mcanally-michael-mcanally-baum-make-marriage-legal/ Shane McAnally, Michael McAnally Baum Make Marriage Legal] ==Discography and videography== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! style="width:10em;"| Title ! style="width:18em;"| Details |- ! scope="row"| ''[[Shane McAnally (album)|Shane McAnally]]'' | * Release date: October 24, 2000 * Label: [[Curb Records|Curb]] * Formats: [[Compact disc|CD]], [[Compact Cassette|cassette]] |} ===Singles=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2"| Year ! rowspan="2" style="width:14em;"| Single ! colspan="2"| Peak chart

On ''[[Songland]]'', McAnally works alongside esteemed producers [[Ryan Tedder]] and [[Ester Dean]], collaborating with unknown songwriters to craft hit songs. Each "winning" song is recorded by that episode's musical guest and released immediately following the episode. McAnally has described his role on the show as his "wildest dream job that I never knew I wanted."
